results.title: ‘Roald Dahl’s Matilda the Musical’ Review: Youth in Revolt
results.abstract: This musical adaptation of Roald Dahl’s novel is a jolt of sour candy guaranteed to make you grin.

results.title: ‘Broker’ Review: It Takes a Village to Sell a Child
results.abstract: Filmed in South Korea, the new movie from Hirokazu Kore-Eda turns a potentially grim tale into a poignant road picture.

results.title: How Angela Lansbury and Stephen Sondheim Came to Appear in ‘Glass Onion’
results.abstract: A fan of musical theater, Rian Johnson had long hoped to land the two stars. But he was already in the editing phase when they agreed to take part.

results.title: ‘Babylon’: A Guide to the Characters and Their Real-Life Counterparts
results.abstract: The Damien Chazelle epic is set in 1920s Hollywood and draws on figures from that time, including “the ‘It’ Girl,” Clara Bow.

multimedia.caption: Clara Bow was the model for Margot Robbie’s character in “Babylon.”
Clara Bow was the model for Margot Robbie’s character in “Babylon.”
Clara Bow was the model for Margot Robbie’s character in “Babylon.”

results.title: Zoey Deutch Enjoys ‘The Joy of Cooking’ and the Occasional Tracksuit
results.abstract: The actor, now in the movie “Something From Tiffany’s,” thrives on regular readings of “Our Town,” discussions of “Sapiens” and whiffs of her dog’s paws.

multimedia.caption: Zoey Deutch stars in “Something From Tiffany’s,” a new holiday movie on Amazon Prime Video.

results.title: ‘Women Talking’ Review: The Power of Speech
results.abstract: Sarah Polley adapts Miriam Toews’s novel into a timely political parable with a stellar ensemble cast.

results.title: ‘Babylon’ and the Case of the Missing Bob Haircut
results.abstract: Margot Robbie’s 1920s silent-screen star wears her locks long and frizzy — and that’s by design, as the director Damien Chazelle and hairstylist explain.

multimedia.caption: Margot Robbie as the longhaired Nellie LaRoy in “Babylon.”
Margot Robbie as the longhaired Nellie LaRoy in “Babylon.”

results.title: Inside the Oscars’ Best-Actress Battle Royal
results.abstract: Forget the men: A banner crop of leading ladies, including Michelle Yeoh and Cate Blanchett, rule the Oscars’ deepest and most dynamic race.

results.title: ‘The Pale Blue Eye’ Review: Stolen Hearts and Tortured Minds
results.abstract: A tormented detective and a fictional Edgar Allan Poe team up to solve grisly killings in this stuffy period melodrama.

results.title: ‘Broadway Rising’ Review: Surviving the Pandemic
results.abstract: Stakeholders including Patti LuPone and Lynn Nottage share their real-time reactions to New York theater’s shutdown and reopening in Amy Rice’s documentary.

multimedia.caption: Rehearsing in masks as shows prepared to reopen, in a scene from “Broadway Rising.”

results.title: How Well Do You Know Modern Variations of “A Christmas Carol”?
results.abstract: Adaptations of this classic holiday story have been appearing on stage and screen for more than a century, but how much do you know about more recent versions?

results.title: How Well Do You Know Your Holiday Movies?
results.abstract: Between a murderous Santa wielding a sledgehammer and an elf throwing a rave in a corporate mailroom, Christmas movies seem to get more outlandish every year.

results.title: Mike Hodges, Director Acclaimed for ‘Get Carter,’ Dies at 90
results.abstract: He was best known for complex crime dramas like “Croupier.” But he also made the big-budget 1980 science-fiction yarn “Flash Gordon.”

multimedia.caption: Mr. Hodges, center, directing “Flash Gordon” (1980). The movie “is cheerfully willing to look as phony as it is,” Roger Ebert wrote. “I don’t mean that as a criticism.”
Mr. Hodges, center, directing “Flash Gordon” (1980). The movie “is cheerfully willing to look as phony as it is,” Roger Ebert wrote. “I don’t mean that as a criticism.”

results.title: ‘Corsage’ Review: A Queen in Quiet Rebellion
results.abstract: A transfixing Vicky Krieps plays the Empress of Austria who, at 40, begins to chafe against her predictably cosseted life.

multimedia.caption: Vicky Krieps as the Empress of Austria, caught between the privileges that at once exalt and suffocate her.

results.title: ‘Babylon’ Review: Boozing. Snorting. That’s Entertainment!?
results.abstract: Damien Chazelle directs Brad Pitt, Margot Robbie and Diego Calva in a 1920s story about Hollywood’s good and sometimes very bad old days.

results.title: ‘No Bears’ Review: A Film That Critiques Itself
results.abstract: The latest feature from Jafar Panahi, who is currently imprisoned in Iran, explores the subversive power and the ethical limitations of filmmaking.

results.abstract: This month’s picks include a look at families coping with cancer, a filmmaker exploring some troubling family history and a director using animation to tell the story of an Afghan refugee.

results.title: Un retrato hablado de Daniel Giménez Cacho, por Cuarón, Del Toro y González Iñárritu
results.abstract: Los tres cineastas más importantes del México contemporáneo recuerdan sus proyectos con el actor. “El mejor actor de nuestra generación”, dice Del Toro, quien le dio un papel en “Cronos”, su ópera prima.

results.title: Musical Adaptation of ‘Almost Famous’ Will Close on Broadway
results.abstract: The show, a passion project for Cameron Crowe, opened on Broadway in early November, but has faced soft sales in a competitive market.

results.title: Amber Heard Says She Has Decided to ‘Settle’ Johnny Depp Defamation Case
results.abstract: The long-running legal battle was heading for its next chapter in an appeals court, but Mr. Depp’s lawyers said Ms. Heard has agreed to pay $1 million to end it.

multimedia.caption: Johnny Depp and Amber Heard at the defamation trial in April. Referring to the prospect of a new trial, Ms. Heard wrote, “I simply cannot go through that for a third time.”

results.title: ‘Avatar: The Way of Water’ Has a Subdued Start at the Box Office
results.abstract: Ticket sales totaled $134 million in North America, nearly doubling the opening for the first ‘Avatar.’ But Hollywood was expecting more.

multimedia.caption: Box office analysts expect “Avatar: The Way of Water,” set on the fantasy moon of Pandora, to gain steam over the holidays. It faces little competition.
